G.L. c. 215.proposition: The parties are subject to the jurisdiction of the Bristol County Probate and Family Court (“this Court”) pursuant to G.L. c. 215 and G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related provisions governing custody and support of minor children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, which permits modification of custody and parenting-time provisions upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the requested modification is in the best interests of the Children.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: The Children have lived in Massachusetts for more than six months preceding the filing of this Complaint, making Massachusetts their home state under G.L. c. 209B (Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court retained continuing jurisdiction over issues of custody and parenting time pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Court’s general equity powers under G.L. c. 215.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody and parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the Children.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Clarifying that the Children’s primary residence shall remain with the Plaintiff, and that scheduling of significant recurring activities will require advance consultation and agreement, will promote stability and predictability for the Children, consistent with G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31 and the principles articulated in Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: In doing so, the Defendant has acted inconsistently with the spirit and letter of joint legal custody, which requires meaningful consultation and shared decision-making on major issues in the Children’s lives, including significant educational and extracurricular commitments.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly defines joint custody as requiring joint decision-making and the ability of both parents to work together on major child-rearing issues such as schooling, medical treatment, religion, and discipline. The court explains that joint custody presupposes mutual cooperation and a willingness to reach results on major decisions similar to married couples, which aligns with the proposition’s description of joint legal custody requiring meaningful consultation and shared decision-making on significant matters in the children’s lives.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests. … [I]n order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … [J]oint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions in a manner similar to the way married couples make decisions.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Children’s physical symptoms (stomach aches on transition days) and their emotional distress constitute a substantial change in circumstances since the 2022 Custody Order was issued, indicating that the current implementation of joint legal custody and the current parenting-time structure are no longer serving their best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case does not address post-judgment modification based on children’s physical or emotional symptoms, nor does it discuss what constitutes a “substantial change in circumstances” under a prior custody order. Instead, it concerns an initial custody determination between unmarried parents and explicitly declines to apply the substantial-change standard of G.L. c. 209C, § 20. Thus, it provides no authority for the proposition that children’s stomach aches on transition days and emotional distress amount to a substantial change warranting alteration of an existing joint custody/parenting-time structure.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Children’s physical symptoms (stomach aches on transition days) and their emotional distress constitute a substantial change in circumstances since the 2022 Custody Order was issued, indicating that the current implementation of joint legal custody and the current parenting-time structure are no longer serving their best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns initial custody determinations in a context of domestic violence and the requirement for explicit findings about the effect of such violence on the child. It does not address modification of an existing custody order based on later-arising physical or emotional symptoms in the child, nor does it discuss what constitutes a “substantial change in circumstances” for modification purposes. Using this case to support the proposition that children’s current physical and emotional distress (e.g., stomach aches on transition days) is a substantial change in circumstances misstates its holding and focus.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, when parents are unable or unwilling to communicate and cooperate effectively in making major decisions for their children, joint legal custody may no longer be in the children’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses joint legal and physical custody and emphasizes that such arrangements generally require parents to be able and willing to cooperate and communicate, quoting Rolde v. Rolde for that principle. However, Mason v. Coleman does not hold that when parents are unable or unwilling to cooperate, joint legal custody may no longer be in the children’s best interests, nor does it modify or terminate joint custody on that basis. The case instead focuses on the standard for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint-custody context, ultimately continuing shared legal and physical custody despite significant parental conflict.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Although the General Laws state that there is no presumption ‘either in favor or against shared . . . custody at the time of trial on the merits,’ G. L. c. 208, § 31, such an arrangement is generally appropriate only if the parties demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate amicably and communicate with one another to raise the children. … ‘[I]n order to be effective ‘joint custody requires ... a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions…’ Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404-405 (1981).”

Custody of Dougherty, 429 Mass. 620 (199.proposition: The Defendant’s persistent disparagement of the Plaintiff to the Children and his interference with the Children’s relationship with the Plaintiff are relevant and weighty factors in determining the best interests of the Children.
Custody of Dougherty, 429 Mass. 620 (199.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about suppression of evidence and the sufficiency of a trafficking verdict; it does not involve family law, custody, or best interests of children. There is no discussion of parental disparagement, interference with a parent–child relationship, or any custody-related best-interests analysis. Accordingly, it cannot serve as authority for the stated proposition regarding disparagement and interference in custody determinations.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The Defendant’s persistent disparagement of the Plaintiff to the Children and his interference with the Children’s relationship with the Plaintiff are relevant and weighty factors in determining the best interests of the Children.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on custody, joint vs. sole physical custody, and removal of the children to Greece under a ‘real advantage’ standard. It contains no discussion of disparagement of one parent by the other, interference with the children’s relationship with the other parent, or how such conduct factors into a best-interests analysis. Because those topics are not addressed in the court’s reasoning, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and when modification is in the “best interests of the children.”
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The case concerns modification of alimony and child support under G.L. c. 208, §§ 37 and 28, not modification of custody. The court articulates the standard for modifying a support or alimony order (material change in circumstances and consideration of needs/financial status) but does not address or apply any standard for modifying custody orders under § 28. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about custody modification and the ‘best interests of the children.’
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. Resolution of the issue rests in the judge’s sound discretion. An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1976, c. 279, § 1.… A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support award.”

Jacobs v. Jacobs, 403 Mass. 71 (1988).proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and when modification is in the “best interests of the children.”
Jacobs v. Jacobs, 403 Mass. 71 (1988).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a partial dissent in a products liability case dealing with negligence and breach of warranty. It does not involve divorce, custody, G.L. c. 208, § 28, or any standard for modification of custody based on a material and substantial change in circumstances or the best interests of the children. Therefore, it does not support the claimed custody‑modification proposition.
Jacobs v. Jacobs, 403 Mass. 71 (1988).relevant_excerpt: As the court said in Hayes v. Ariens Co., 391 Mass. 407, 410 (1984), “[a] defendant cannot be found to have been negligent without having breached the warranty of merchantability.” Contrary to the court’s assertion, ante at 77, the deceased’s use of the product did not “at best, raise[] only the issue of the comparative negligence of the deceased.”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that when a parent’s conduct interferes with the children’s relationship with the other parent, fails to support that relationship, or exposes the children to ongoing conflict and disparagement, modification of custody and parenting arrangements may be necessary to protect the children’s best interests.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion affirms a custody award to the father where a central concern was the mother’s conduct in thwarting the father’s relationship with the child and denying him participation in important decisions, which the court explicitly treated as contrary to the child’s best interests. Although styled as an initial custody determination rather than a post‑judgment "modification," the court’s reasoning fits the proposition that interference with the other parent’s relationship and inability to communicate can justify changing custody/parenting arrangements to protect the child. The case is therefore reasonably supportive though not a paradigmatic modification case.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the mother has "dismissed the need of [the child] for a [f]ather" and has "thwarted his joint legal custody at every turn." "She has denied him information about and input into the most important decisions and events concerning the child: medical issues, hospitalizations, attendance at preschool, selection of pre-school educational programs, all to the detriment of [the child]." ... The judge emphasized that "[a]ccess for the child to each parent is an important consideration for the [c]ourt" and that, while the mother has consistently denied the father participation in fundamental decisions concerning the child, the father ... has "demonstrated that he will not deny [the child] access to [the] mother."

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that when a parent’s conduct interferes with the children’s relationship with the other parent, fails to support that relationship, or exposes the children to ongoing conflict and disparagement, modification of custody and parenting arrangements may be necessary to protect the children’s best interests.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about crediting Social Security disability dependency benefits against a child support obligation and, secondarily, about attachment of assets and the adequacy of findings supporting a change from shared to sole legal custody. While it mentions that custody modifications must be in the child’s best interests, it does not discuss parental interference with the other parent’s relationship, failure to support that relationship, or exposing children to conflict or disparagement as grounds for modification. The sole articulated basis for changing legal custody was the parties’ inability to communicate, and the SJC ultimately vacates that modification for lack of findings, so the case does not establish the proposition claimed.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that ‘the parties are unable to communicate with one another.’ … [T]he judge ‘failed to make specific or detailed findings … that awarding sole legal custody … was in the best interests of the child.’”
